summary: The film follows the misadventures of Jack Skellington, Halloweentown's beloved pumpkin king, who has become bored with the same annual routine of frightening people in the "real world." When Jack accidentally stumbles on Christmastown, all bright colors and warm spirits, he gets a new lease on life -- he plots to bring Christmas under his control by kidnapping Santa Claus and taking over the role. But Jack soon discovers even the best-laid plans of mice and skeleton men can go seriously awry.

I know this doesn't sound very Tim Burton, but I think with an improved script and storyline combined with the visual effects and animation The Nightmare Before Christmas could be something special.

The best word to describe Nightmare Before Christmas is bizarre. On the one hand it is bizarre for how blatantly surreal its settings and atmospheres are, masterfully staged through a use of state-of-the-art stop-motion. On the other hand, it is bizarre for how blatantly basic its plot, characters and writing are; a movie that is clearly not made only for children, seems to have been written by a child especially when compared to other animated movies of those years. But probably the intent was neither to set up a particularly deep writing nor to create particularly stratified characters, but rather to transport the viewer into an incredibly gothic world dripping with a creepy atmosphere; and in this Nightmare Before Christmas succeeds flawlessly.

I admit it, I really like Tim Burton. I know his films are very oddball, but he has a wide imagination and his films are visually amazing. And I like a vast majority of his films, Edward Scissorhands being my personal favourite, and I love Batman and Batman Returns too. Henry Sellick is also promising, from the likes of James and the Giant Peach and Coraline. The Nightmare Before Christmas is a brilliant film. Is it an animated classic. Yes I think it is! It is wonderfully weird yet lots of fun as well. Visually and technically, the film looks absolutely amazing, with wonderful Gothic backgrounds and detailed colouring. Skellington silhouetted against the moonlight is quite possibly the film's most haunting image. The story is great, about Jack Skellington discovering ChristmasTown but doesn't understand the concept so he kidnaps Santa Claus. And the characters are endearing and weird, ranging from jazz playing zombies, Four-tenor like vampires to a wolf man. Then we have the title characters, Jack Skellington is a wonderful protagonist, really interesting to say the least. And Sally for an inventor's creation is very beautiful. The songs from Danny Elfman(the fact that he didn't get an award for his score for Edward Scissorhands is the biggest music snubs ever) are great fun, haunting, funny, clever and intelligent. The voice acting is top notch, Chris Sarandon does a great job as the speaking voice of Skellington, and Danny Elfman himself provides the singing voice superbly. Catherine O'Hara is sweet and innocent, and Ken Page(the voice of King Gator in All Dogs Go To Heaven) is a hoot as Oogie Boogie. All in all, weird, but visually stunning, funny and intelligent animated movie. A definite classic! 10/10 Bethany Cox

I quite enjoyed both the characters and the musical numbers. I quite like that its relatively fast paced at times - its certainly a bit of fun and it looks pretty good in HD. I appreciate well done stop motion animation and this is certainly one of those. If you haven't seen it, I'd say its worth a watch. Its not particularly amazing or brilliantly memorable, I suppose but its certainly not bad, or frustratingly depressing for that matter, either.

"The Nightmare Before Christmas" is such an amazing stop motion animated horror film that I always loved to watch every Halloween!  The visuals are beautiful and creepy at the same time and I just loved the creative and horrifying world of Halloween Town as it's full of monsters and creatures that will haunt your dreams!  I especially loved the main character Jack Skellington himself as he's such a charismatic and fun loving character that made me love every scene that he's in!  I also really liked Sally the Rag Doll, who loves Jack Skellington and tries to prevent him from getting into trouble when Jack wanted to be Santa Claus for that year (despite the fact that he's a living skeleton and he only knows how to scare people).  The music was fantastic as well, as my favorite songs are "What's This?" and "Sally's Song" and I enjoy listening to this music every year!  My only gripe with this film is that I wished that some of the characters' backstories were developed, like the main antagonist Oogie Boogie.  Overall, "The Nightmare Before Christmas" is one of the greatest stop motion horror films ever made and it's definitely worth the watch!

So I'll probably get a lot of flack for this review but here we go: It's TNBC. To many people it's Tim's magnum opus. It's everywhere; in Spencer's and Hot Topic.. The soundtrack is FLAWLESS. I still love it. You should also listen to Nightmare Revisted. The technical aspects are amazing and I have mad respect for anyone who uses stop motion. Now with the positives, I must say... I don't think it deserves to be Tim's "Spotlight movie". It's simplistic but at the same time the end message seems to be "If you're not good at something stick to what you know instead" and that's discouraging. I think other Burton movies deserve the same love as TNBC and this IS coming from someone who worshipped this movie like it was some kind of religion before. Tldr: It's simple, charming, but oversaturated everywhere.

He gets excited about Christmas, and tries to institute it in Halloweentown. Unfortunately, he doesn't understand the concept and it turns out badly. They even kidnap Santa Claus (voiced by Edward Ivory).

Jack Skillington, finding Halloween a bit of a bore, decides to kidnap Santa and deliver all of the Christmas gifts himself.  While the plot is simple in design, Tim Burton's The Nightmare Before Christmas is a visually stunning movie, with stop motion animation like it has never been seen before.  The images pop from the screen and are almost three dimensional in their depth.  It's a movie that needs to be seen more than once to fully appreciate the animation, the first time to watch the main characters and the second time to admire everything that is going on in the background.  While Danny Elfman's songs, and there are plenty of them, are mostly immediately forgettable, the Elfman score is absolutely fantastic.

This is a classic!  I originally viewed it in 1993 when it first was released.  With all the CGI fx that are done in recent years - it was a pleasure and artistic to see some stop action animation and models for the characters used in the making of this film.  The story is beutiful in a Tim Burtonesque world.  I happen to be a huge fan of TB, and this work of art brought me back to earlier days in filmmaking.  The characters are very real in their emotions and the theme is that just because you are different doesn't mean you are a freak.  This underlying theme is used in many of TB's films - e.g. Edward Scissorhands (wish they'd re-release that gem and Beetlejuice (playing now) and also Sweeny Todd and most of his body of work - I am not a fan of Mars Attacks! - but that probably is the only TB film that did not quite make the usual creativity level of TB's productions.  He is also an artist, doing some great sculptures that are involved in many of his films.  A true American classic - I imagine it has been shown all over the globe in foreign languages. THE NIGHTMARE BEFORE CHRISTMAS is a delightful blend of goth, Christmas cheer, and all things Burtonesque, albeit not directed by Tim Burton. Danny Elfman's musical numbers are upbeat and stunningly performed, and the claymation visuals are top-notch.
